the following program contains inconvenient truth and controversial topics that may be offensive to some audiences.  listener discretion is advised.  And now, the Commander-in-Chief is back.  Freedom Friday with Carl Gallops, the Oval Office of Gulf Coast Talk Radio.  All right, folks, we are back.  It's another Friday afternoon, so may the Lord bless you.  Thank you for joining us today.  We're live on this Friday afternoon.  So I've got Messianic Rabbi Zev Perat.  He is on the line.  He's out of Tel Aviv.  It is late in the evening there, but he's on.  live with us.  Zev, it's so good to have you with us, man, from Tel Aviv.  I guess it's getting on around midnight there, huh?
After midnight.  It's great to be here, Carl.  Thank you for having me on.

Oh, man, it's so good to have you.  And I always enjoy having you on, Zev.  I'm speaking right now to Messianic Rabbi Zev Perat, born and raised in an Orthodox Jewish family, born and bred to be an Orthodox Jewish rabbi, was in school training to do that, actually graduated from the rabbinical training school, really qualified to be a Sanhedrin rabbi, immersed in it.  His father was a rabbi.  His grandfather was a rabbi.  His great-grandfather was a rabbi, all very prominent rabbinical family.  But in the midst of all of that, he came to, in Hebrew, Yeshua HaMashiach, Jesus Christ as Messiah and Lord.  It was a long process.  His testimony is in the book, The Rabbi, the Secret Message, and the Identity of Messiah.  Zev and I wrote that together.  It's going all over the world.  It's leading Orthodox and even secular Jews to the Lord all over the world.  But he is now a Messianic rabbi.  That is, rabbi is just the Hebrew word for teacher, preacher.  And Messianic means he's a believer that Yeshua, Jesus, is the Messiah.  So Messianic rabbi, Zev Peratt.  It's good to have you with us, Zev.
It's great to be here.  We are living in exciting and prophetic times.  What you're seeing in the United States is also happening here in Israel for the good and for the best.

Yeah, I know.  I mean, for the good, the gospel's going out and a lot of people are asking questions because a lot of people who don't even know the word of God or don't think about it much or don't talk about it much, they're realizing that something is snapping in the world, something prophetic.  Something prophetic is in the air.  I mean, this is just too surreal.  And so people are asking questions.  And I know that's happening with you.  The bad is the world is coming unglued at the seams in all of the ways that the Scripture predicted it would happen.  in the days before the return of the Lord.  And even though you and I don't set dates, we understand we're living in prophetic times.  I'm going to hush now, and you do all the rest of the talking, but just tell our folks what's going on in Israel concerning the protesting over the George Floyd killing in the United States.  I mean, with all due respect to George Floyd and everybody involved in that, what in the world does Israel have to do with this, and why are there protests and people upset about all of that in Israel?

Well, first of all, when you look at a video of something like that happening anywhere in the world, it's very, very troubling.  Here in Israel, on the news, every day, on Israeli news, every day they're showing that video.  Every day they're speaking about it.  And I think a lot of it has to do with the fact that there were a few violent issues here in Israel several months ago and also several years ago involving the Ethiopian Jewish community here in Israel that unfortunately had some police that... We're out of line, and, you know, it was labeled as racism.  We're not saying that the Israeli police are racist.  We're not saying that the government is.  But we are saying that there are a few that, you know, stepped over the line, just like the ones in America that we see.  And that's, you know, waking up the line, as they say.  And here in Israel, the demonstrations for George Floyd and for an Ethiopian soldier that was killed by military police here in Israel – and some of the arrests that they show on TV in the last couple of months and couple of years that these Ethiopian Jews were mistreated.  So they're saying, what's to stop Israel from what's happening in America to happen here also?  And therefore, black lives do matter, and this is where the protests begin.  It started also in the beginning of June this month, but it's happening again this week.  It's not only in Tel Aviv.  It's happening in small rallies in Jerusalem.  It's happening in Tiberias.  It's happening all over the country.  And the first Israeli woman Ethiopian in the Israeli government, she's a lawyer, Pina Tamnushata, is a voice right now for the Ethiopian people.  And actually, the reason she was put in government... is because of what happened to the Ethiopian people here in Israel.  But Netanyahu is saying, you know, whether the blue and white are going to continue or not, he wants her in government because he wants a voice for the black community here in Israel because they're trying to label Netanyahu and the Recruit Party as racist.  You know, they do the same thing in America, but, you know, we're trying to clear that up.  So that's the reason the George Floyd killing happened.  is causing a riot here in Israel as well, and it's understandable.  However, in the midst of this bad situation, the gospel is going forth.  We have a large, huge Ethiopian community here in Israel that we're able to preach the gospel to them.  We're able to touch them with the love of Jesus, the love of Yeshua.  A lot of them are hurt.  It's true.  I mean, a lot of times they don't get good jobs because of that reason.  I'm not saying, again, that Israel is like that everywhere, but there is a problem all over the world And the only way the problem can be solved is through the Bible, is through the love of Jesus Yeshua.  Many, many times here in Israel, they would come to us Ethiopian people and say, why are you preaching the gospel to us?  We're low in society here.  They feel like that a lot of times.  And we say, did you know that Moshe, Moses, also married a woman that was probably Ethiopian?  Most scholars believe she was Ethiopian.  And they say, really, we didn't know that.  And we open the book of Numbers, we show them, and the gospel can go forth.  So we're using this crazy situation to do that here in Israel.

Yes, that's amazing.  Hey, listen, let me just ask you a couple of questions.  First of all, thank you for that breakdown and for that information.  You told me a lot of stuff I didn't know, so I know our audience probably appreciated that as well.  So let me ask you this.  Two questions.  They're kind of unrelated, but I think they'll be easy for you to answer.  Number one, what's the demographic of black Israelis in Israel?  I know in the United States, the entire black population in the United States is around 20 percent, maybe a little bit less.  So what is it in Israel?  And then secondly, what's the current state of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu?  Is he officially prime minister?  Are they still sharing it?  I mean, we've kind of dropped off the radar of international news as to what's going on with all of that.  So those two questions, if you could hit that for us.

Well, in the 1980s and 90s, there was big aliyah, aliyah is immigration of Ethiopian Jews to Israel.  So the population is about 20% right now and growing.  So it's probably like around the United States.  And regarding Benjamin Netanyahu, of course, he is the prime minister of Israel.  Together with the blue and white parliament, which is the Benny Gantz, they're kind of joint in government right now.  They say in the name of the COVID-19, but we all understand what's happening behind the scenes over here.  The agreement is this call that Benjamin Netanyahu will be the prime minister of Israel for the next 18 months.  And then after 18 months, he's supposed to give his seat over to the blue and white party, which is Benny Gantz.  Most people, myself included, do not think that's going to happen.  We think either there's going to be a fourth election or Benny Gantz somehow is going to be taken out of the government.  A lot of people think that it's kind of a trap for Benny Gantz.  Time will tell.  In the midst of all this, Benjamin Netanyahu has been indicted, and Benny Gantz has already tried to make sure that he would probably not be the prime minister.  That didn't work.  Netanyahu says he's innocent.  He asked the Israeli government on television and on the newspaper, please televise.  Everything that I say in the court.  Bring the cameras in.  I allow it, and they refuse to do it.  I remember that.

Listen, we're going to have to go to break, and then you can pick up in just a minute, Zev.  Folks, thank you so much for listening to us today.  Zev's going to be back right after this break.  The break is only going to be two minutes, so please don't go anywhere.  Just two brief minutes.  You're in the Oval Office, Gulf Coast Talk Radio, Freedom Friday with Carl Gallops, Peter Lazor, my world-famous producer, Messianic Rabbi Zev Perat, my guest this afternoon.  We'll be right back.  After this brief, brief timeout.  You're listening to Freedom Friday with Carl Gallups from the Oval Office of the Gulf Coast.  Don't change that dial.  We're just getting started.  Freedom Friday with Carl Gallups, the Oval Office of Gulf Coast Talk Radio.  That's right.  If you change the dial, you'll be sorry that you did.  I promise you.  Messianic Rabbi Zefarat from Tel Aviv, Israel is on the line with us.  So good to have you back.  We were talking about Netanyahu and the plans after the 18 months, and you were prognosticating as to what you thought would probably happen in reality with that.  Why don't you continue with that, and then we'll go on with our discussion.

Well, yeah, 18 months, and then he's supposed to get the seat open for Benny Gantz.  People, you know, like to ask the question here in Israel, and they've asked it on the news.  You know, here in the news in Israel, every night you watch the news, it's like a boxing match.  They just kill each other on the news.  They like that here in Israel, and they allow it, too.  So anyways, the questions are always asked, why would you let Benny Gantz have your seat in 18 months?  And his answer is, well, because we have to deal with the issue of the COVID-19 right now.  The answer is not even logical, his answer.  But everybody knows that he has some kind of a plan up his sleeve, as they say here in Israel, to get Benny Gantz out.  I don't think Benny Gantz is going to be here in eight months.  Time will tell.  But we'll play this program again and see where we are in eight months.  Having said that, Netanyahu has been indicted.  But once again, he claims and his lawyers claim that he's innocent, that it's a trap from the leftists to try to get him out of government.  That's probably what it is.  He says, I've got nothing to hide.  Put it on television.  And they refuse to do it.  And the reason they refuse to do it is because they don't have anything on them.  They're just trying to get them out of government.  But anyways, it's going to take much more than 18 months until we find out that result.  But having said that, here in Israel right now, we're seeing something in these demonstrations for George Floyd in Tel Aviv and other places.  We're seeing unity between Arabs and Jews.  I was in the streets today, Friday, and I watched Arabs and Jews unite together because of what happened in America.  So God is turning this evil situation into good.  And right now, to see the Jews and the Arabs together saying black lives matter is You know, it's huge here in Israel.  It's opening something new.

Well, listen, what is the response of people in Israel if you were to respond, well, you know, really, all lives matter.  Of course black lives matter.  I mean, when you say all lives matter, that means black, white, brown.  Brown, yellow, all lives matter.  Of course, black lives matter.  But if they come back and say, no, no, no, it's black lives, then what they're saying is that the black race is above all other races.  Now, that is the definition of racism.  If I were to get on the radio and say the white race is above all races just because we're white.  Well, that's racist, see?  But what a born-again believer would say is, look, all lives matter.  The life in the womb, the life of every human being on the planet, there's nothing special about any of them.  Now, is this a situation that we need to deal with?  Yes.  But what are they saying in Israel if you try to say all lives matter?

Well, that's what we do.  We preach the gospel, and you know Romans 2.11 says, for God shows no partiality.  With God, there is no color.  God's came for, you know, for everybody who died on the cross, on the tree, for everyone, Jesus.  And therefore, again, I'm saying this opens the gospel.  That's why I was speaking about the Arabs and the Jews together, that, you know, it's, okay, we understand that what the protest is saying, but we're using it to say yes, and God loves everyone, and we love everyone.  So that's the message, and that's what we're doing here in Israel.  And I agree.  I mean, there is a danger in labeling, you know, a certain sector, you know, the Jews matter, or the Christians matter, or the blacks matter, or the Indians, everybody matters.

Or the Arabs matter, or just, yeah.  Muslim lives matter.  Well, of course they do.  Yeah.  And so do Christian lives, and so do Jewish lives.  And then the Muslims say, oh, no, no, no, you can't say that.  Then that's racist.  But you see, that's happening in the United States.  And I don't know if you would know that or not, but over here, if we try to just talk common sense and common humanity and common decency to people and say, yes, what happened to George Floyd was horrible.  We're going to rectify that where the legal system is going to take care of that.  Within three days of it happening, the officer was arrested for murder.  He's in jail.  That's going to be taken care of.  But to say Black Lives Matter, and they don't add the word only Black Lives Matter, but that's what they mean.  Because if you say really all lives matter, they go berserk.  They lose their minds.  It's a derangement of mind.  It's absolutely unbelievable.  I was just wondering if you guys deal with that kind of reaction when you try to talk to people.
Absolutely, we deal with it.  And again, you're right.  This can create hatred in the opposite direction.  And so there is a danger in doing that.  We agree.
Yeah.

But I think here in Israel also it's the same problem, because we had a lot of people from the United States that were making aliyah that were also African American.  We do have some African American Jews here in Israel that made aliyah, and they were using that kind of language.  It would cause a little bit of a problem, but if you look at some of the signs on the video that are in Hebrew... it does say that, you know, everybody matters.  So that was good to see on the signs in Hebrew.

Yeah, well, that's very interesting.  Thank you for that.  And you keep talking about making aliyah, and early in the program you explained it, but just for our listeners, explain again what that means.  It's Hebrew for immigrating, but explain to them what making aliyah means.

Well, Aliyah means basically going up.  So in Hebrew, when you return to Israel, you're not returning to Israel, you're going up.  In a way, they got it right, because the New Jerusalem is going to be up.  They got half right.  So when you think about making Aliyah, Aliyah means going up, to go up.  But in English, it's immigrating to Israel.  So that's why it's called Aliyah, going up, going back to Israel.  Basically, Israel opens the doors for anybody that can show that they're Jewish, from any nation, from any race, from any background, And so we have all kinds of backgrounds here in Israel, which is beautiful, which is great, which is what God wants.  And so that's why we have African Americans from the States, and that's why we have Ethiopians from Ethiopia, and that's why we have people from Nigeria.  We have everybody here in Israel.

Well, listen, listen, I support Aliyah totally.  I support everything you just said, but I'm sitting here thinking, That is amazing.  I am so surprised that Israel is not called xenophobic in that regard, because can you imagine if the United States said, OK, immigration, if you can prove you're a Christian and you are from European roots, because that's where our founding colonies came from, we'll let you in and we'll make you a citizen.  If you can't prove you're a Christian or from European roots, then you can't come here.  And I mean, if you think about that, brother, but I understand Israel is a very special case.  It's a small sliver of land.  And of course, it originally belonged to the Jewish people.  So I get it.  And you know me, brother.  I support Israel's right to exist.  And I support Aliyah.  But I'm just thinking the people in America... Most of them don't even have a clue what that's all about.  The liberals, the leftists in our nation, their heads would explode if they understood this.
Well, absolutely, and that's why we have 9.2 or 9.3 million people in Israel.  It sounds like not a lot, but if you go back a decade, what, there's only 6 million here.
That's right.

So we're growing a lot because of Aliyah, because of immigration, and because it's an end-time sign that we're getting close to the end.  It's one of the signs of the return of Israel.  And now the demographics of Israel are growing at a rapid pace, and it's going to continue to grow because as anti-Semitism increases in the world, more Jews are coming back to Israel.

Yeah, yeah.  There are more Jews that live in the land of Israel now than have ever lived there, even under King David, even under King Solomon.  More Jews in Israel than ever, which is the fulfillment of a prophecy of the return of Israel.  Zev, I'll give you the last 10 seconds.  Love you, man.  Thanks for coming on.
Well, thank you for having me.  And again, all lives matter.
